lessonOutcomes.outcome: Students can correctly use “have/has got” in positive and negative statements and Yes/No questions.
supportStrategies: (Grammar) On the board write: “I’ve got a ___ / I haven’t got a ___.” and “He’s got a ___ / He hasn’t got a ___.” Students complete orally with toys.
stretchStrategies: ❝Sentence Build Relay❞ – Divide the class into two teams. On the board, write “He/She has/hasn’t got ___.” Students take turns running to complete the sentence using toy flashcards or pictures, then read it aloud.

lessonOutcomes.outcome: Students can recognise and identify the sounds “th” and “ee”.
supportStrategies: (Phonics) Write th, ee on the board. Say: “/th/ is in ‘three’. /ee/ is in ‘feet.’” Students find more words in the SB.
stretchStrategies: ❝Sentence Build Relay❞ – Divide the class into two teams. On the board, write “He/She has/hasn’t got ___.” Students take turns running to complete the sentence using toy flashcards or pictures, then read it aloud.

lessonOutcomes.outcome: Students can complete short sentence frames to answer Yes/No questions about possessions.
supportStrategies: (Writing) Show frames: “Have you got a ___?” “Yes, I have.” Students fill in blanks using target vocab from previous units.

Do not exist in standard Vietnamese, written or spoken. The hardest part for YLs is learning to pronounce them naturally: there's a dog rather than there is a dog.

In Vietnamese, final consonants are 'held in' – you don't actually hear them released. But in English, the final consonant of cat, top, rock, and so on are released with a puff of air. Make sure you are aware of this difference.
